EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (January 2025)
SEA-3, LLC Wholesale Liquefied Propane Gas (LPG) Import & Distribution Terminal

Introduction:

This 5-year resubmittal update is provided to ensure compliance with EPA's 40 CFR 68 Risk Management Program (RMP) and OSHA Process Safety Management Program (29 CFR 1910.119) requirements.

Facility Description:

The Sea-3 Newington, NH facility is located on 190 Shattuck Way in Newington, NH and was originally constructed in 1974 through 1975 and was modified with an expansion in 2019 and 2020.   Sea-3 LLC. owns and operates a 560,000 barrel fully refrigerated propane import/export storage facility in Newington, NH on the Piscataqua River approximately 6.5 miles upstream from the sea buoy at Portsmouth, NH.  The site consists of a total area of 10.8 acres. There are two aboveground storage tanks (AST) containing propane, one 400,000 barrels, the other 160,000 barrels located on 7.02 "upland" acres.   The two ASTs are situated within a large diked area.   Additionally, three (3) 90,000 gallon above ground horizontal storage tanks were added to the facility in 2019.  The railcar loading/unloading facilities and flare are situated on 3.80 acres of "riparian land", separated by the Pan Am railway right-of-way. The dock serving the terminal is upstream of Sea-3's land and is owned by Sprague Energy Corporation. 

In 2017, Blackline acquired Sea-3 Inc. and the Newington terminal, a joint venture formed by Blackline Partners LLC and TPG Sixth Street Partners.  This acquisition allowed for further investment and modernization of the facility.  Under Blackline Partners, the terminal continued its essential role in New England's propane distribution network. Blackline Partners focused on operational safety, regulatory compliance, and maintaining the terminals crucial role in energy distribution, especially in supporting New Englands heating needs during peak winter months.

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & RESPONSE POLICIES:

Sea-3 management

LPG liquid under pressure is loaded onto transport trucks for shipment to customers.  

Ethyl mercaptan, an odorizing agent, is received and stored and then added to LPG being loaded into tank trucks and distributed from the terminal per NFPA-58 requirements.   

Propylene is used as a refrigerant in the railcar refrigeration system.  It is received in pressurized containers and transferred to the refrigeration system.

Propane, ethyl mercaptan and propylene are regulated flammable RMP and PSM substances held above their threshold quantity. The terminal is absent any other RMP or PSM listed flammable or toxic chemicals at or above threshold quantities.

3. RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:

The terminal was designed and built in accordance with provisions of the following three recognized standards for LPG facilities:

- NFPA 58, Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases, (National Fire Protection Association).

- API 2510, Design and Construction of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Installations, (American Petroleum Institute).

- API 620, Design and Construction of Large, Welded, Low-Pressure Storage Tanks, (American Petroleum Institute).

-API 510 Maintenance, Inspection, and Repairs for Pressure Vessels.

-API 570 Maintenance, Inspection, and Repairs for Piping Systems. 

-AMSE codes for Fired Boilers and Weld Repair Requirements. 

Operating areas of the plant are monitored by combustible vapor detectors that quickly detect and alarm if there are any leaks.  Ultraviolet flame detectors monitor the plant to detect fires.  The plant is attended by at least two operators at all times.  They log field operating data at two-hour intervals and monitor plant equipment using the following monitoring and control systems:

3a.	The Main Control

Panel located in the central control room and displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.

3b.	The Railcar human machine interface (HMI) Control Panel located in the new railcar control room displays pressures, temperatures, valve positions, and flow rates and provides for remote operation and manual or automatic shutdown of valves and equipment.  Data from this control system is also displayed in the Main Control Room Panel above.

3c.	The emergency control panel and HMI are located in the Main control room in the upper plant which displays readings of combustible vapor detectors and fire detectors.  It provides fire department notification and manual and automatic activation of water deluge and emergency shutdown systems.  A like emergency panel is in the railcar control room and communicates with the main control room emergency panel. 

3d.	A closed-circuit television (CCTV) system, with displays located in the central control room.  This is used for surveillance and security of all portions of the terminal including the railcar, ship dockage as well as the key operating areas.

The terminal has written policies, procedures, and accident release prevention policies (some listed in section 1).  Besides these there are safe operation P&Ps contained in the following Sea-3 manuals:

- "Sea-3 Standard Operating Procedures Manual" covering normal startup, operation, and shutdown of plant systems and equipment.  The railcar expansion procedures have been developed and added.

- "Sea-3 Safety Standards and Procedures Manual" covering safe handling of the product and other materials used in the plant.  It covers safe work practices and permitting requirements for such activities as hot work, electrical work, lockout/tagout, confined space and vessel entry, excavation, and other hazardous activities.  Plant security and visitor policies are also included.

- "

Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual" covering operation of the marine transfer portion of the terminal as required by 33 CFR 127. 

- "Sea-3 Contingency Plan" covering responses by facility, employees, the Newington Fire and Police Departments, as well as the US Coast Guard.  Its purpose is to minimize the effects of an incident at the terminal and to provide protection for persons and property in the area.  It includes plans for sounding an alarm, initial response, determination of need for additional assistance, flammable vapor control, firefighting, first aid, evacuation of personnel and nearby residents, mutual aid support and propane industry group response.

- "Sea-3 Mooring Policy and Procedure Manual" covering the safe mooring of LPG carriers at the berth during cargo transfers. 

- "Sea-3 Facility Security Plan" covering security as required by the US Department of Homeland Security, as well as PSM and RMP regulations.

- "Sea-3 Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP Manual" covering the elements of PSM and RMP, including employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor evaluation and training, truck driver (non-employee) evaluation and training, pre-startup safety reviews, equipment mechanical integrity, safe work permit system, management of change, incident investigation, and emergency preparedness.  The complete list is included in Section 1 Accident Release Prevention Program.

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

In the five-year reporting period, there have been no propane or ethyl mercaptan releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

Emergency planning and preparedness are covered in the "Sea-3 Contingency Plan" which details responses by facility employees, the Newington Fire

and Police Departments, and the U.S. Coast Guard.  These agencies were involved in the development of the plan which is available to all cognizant officials in the pamphlet "Sea-3 Emergency Procedures."  The sections involving facility employees were developed by Sea-3 management in conjunction with the operating staff and outside consultants.  All new employees are given initial training in health safety and emergency and operation procedures.  

Employees receive refresher training on an ongoing basis.  This training is documented in accordance with the training records requirements of OSHA's Process Safety Management program and EPA's Risk Management Program.  Sea-3 staff receive Fire School classroom and live fire training.

In addition to the Sea-3 Emergency Procedures noted above, emergency response is also covered in the "Sea-3 US Coast Guard Operating and Emergency Procedures Manual."  The US Coast Guard also maintains its own written operating and emergency plan, "Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Contingency Plan" issued by the USCG Marine Safety Office in Portland, Maine.

6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The facility has been in operation since 1975.  Safety reviews as well as compliance audits; Process Hazards Analysis, (PHA) etc., have been undertaken periodically since that time.  All issues have been addressed and many recommendations arising from these reviews have been implemented through equipment additions and/or changes as well as procedural changes.

The sea-3 facility in 2025 plans on recertifying the facility operators on the Sea-3 OPs.  The facility is also planning to conduct a Table Top exercise with the Newington, NH Fire Department. 

7.0 PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT (PSM)/RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP) PROGRAM ELEMENTS:

This section discusses the elements of the PSM/RMP program elements:

7a. PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION:

The Sea-3 facility maintains process safety information (PSA) including toxicity, permissible exposure limits, physical,

reactivity, corrosivity and chemical data on propane, ethyl mercaptan, and propylene.   Piping & Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs), design codes and standards, material balances, electrical classification and emergency relief system design are included in the facility PSI.   PSI is updated accordingly as process changes take place, equipment modifications are made or when new chemicals are introduced into the facility.  The facility is designed and operated in conformance with NFPA 58 - Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases. 

7b. PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS: 

The most recent facility Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed on December 13, 2022 and included a Hazard & Operability Study (HAZOP).  The HAZOP involved participation from eight (8) of the Blackline Midstream employees and one (1) external team member who functioned as the facilitator and scribe.    There were eighty-three (83) Nodes analyzed for safety and health, environmental, community and business consequences of interest. Two-Hundred Ninety-Seven (297) scenarios and consequences were safety risk ranked.  This methodology resulted in forty-eight (48) recommendations. 

7c. OPERATING PROCEDURES:

The facility maintains its operating procedures (OP) and reviews the procedures on an annual basis or more often to reflect current practice.   The OPs have been developed to address safe operating limits including consequence of deviations, safety and health considerations, and safety systems.  OPs have been prepared for Initial Start-Up, Emergency Shut-down, Breaking into Lines, Control of Entry into the Facility, Lock-Out Tag-Out, Confined Space Entry, and Hot Work, etc.

7d. TRAINING:

The Sea-3 facility provides employee training on its OPs, health and safety hazards, safe work practices, and on its emergency operations.   Refresher training is provided every three (3) years and when an accident or incident occurs at the facility.    Employee training programs include a combi

nations of training methods such as classroom training, interactive exercises, focused training videos and hands on training.   Leaning is measured by utilizing quizzes, instructor participant questioning, and a demonstration of equipment competency as required.  

7e. MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:

The facility mechanical integrity (MI) program focuses on the maintenance, repair and testing of facility equipment including the LPG aboveground storage tanks (ASTs), tanks offloading and loading piping systems, safety relief venting systems, pumps, compressors, and system controls.   Sea-3 maintenance employees receive training on the process and hazards associated with the work they are performing.   The MI program also involves inspection and testing of the equipment to ensure that it continues to operate in accordance with its design parameters.  Inspections and equipment testing are scheduled on a weekly and monthly basis according the established equipment PM schedule.  

7f. MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:

Management of Change (MOC) procedures are in place at the Sea-3 facility that address the technical basis for the change, the impact on employee health and safety, a description of the modifications to the OPs as required, the time frame needed to complete the changes and authorizations indicating review and approval of the subject MOC modifications.   PSI and OPs are updated and revised accordingly based on the conditions noted in the MOC.  Employees are informed when a MOC is implemented to ensure that they understand any potential safety hazards and how the changes will impact facility operations. 

7g. PRE-STARTUP REVIEWS:

Pre-startup safety reviews (PSRs) are performed at the Sea-3 facility when modifications represent significant changes to the facility operations on employee safety.   The focus of the facility pre-start up reviews are to identify, confirm and verify that the equipment satisfies the design specifications and parameters, that appropriate procedures are in

place for safe operations and to address emergencies.   Sea-3 employees involved in the Pre-startup undergone training on the process.   When the Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted for modifications or the addition of a new process to facility operations or equipment the PHA and MOC are also updated as required.

7h. COMPLIANCE AUDITS:

The Sea-3 facility most recent Compliance Audit (CA) was completed on October 31, 2022.  The CA reviewed all the program elements of the PSM Plan and the RMP.   The CA was conducted by one external auditor and two Blackline Partners employees including the Terminal Operations Manager, Jay Griffin and the Maintenance Manager, Paul Winkley.  The audit identified 98 findings which resulted in 41 corrective action recommendations to enhance regulatory compliance at the Sea-3, LLC Newington, NH Propane Terminal's PSM/RMP program.  

7i. INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS:

To date the Sea-3 facility has had no major incidents which required investigation.   Should an incident occur the Sea-3 facility does have an incident investigation (II) process in place that initiates an investigation promptly on or before within 48-hours, establishes a team to conduct the investigation, prepares an investigation report identifying what occurred and the root cause of the incident, identifies appropriate corrective actions, and retains the written report for documentation purposes and further reference.  

7j. EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:

Sea-3 employees participate in and are involved in a number of the PSM/RMP program elements including the PHA, CA, MI, OPs, II, PSRs, and Hot Work (HW).   The Sea-3 facility recognizes the importance of employee involvement in its OSHA safety programs and RMP program elements and includes employee representation to ensure that employee involvement and engagement is included in the PHA, and required OSHA programs including personal protective equipment, Lock-out Tag-out, HAZCOM/GHS, HW, and other programs accordingly.

7k. HOT

WORK PERMIT:

The Sea-3 facility operates under a Hot Work (HW) program realizing that propane poses a serious explosion hazard.   The HW program includes procedures to issue a HW Permit (HWP),  implement fire protection and prevention measures, limits the HWP to a specified time and date, described the approved work to be performed under the HWP, and maintains a record of issued HWP.   Additionally, a HWP is required under the New Hampshire Fire code NFPA 1 - Fire Code. 

7l. CONTRACTORS:

The Sea-3 facility does engage contractors as needed to maintain its facility and propane operations.  Prior to engaging and selecting any contractors to perform work at the facility their past safety record and performance is reviewed.  The Sea-3 facility further verifies that the contractor employees have been trained by their respective employer(s) to perform the work safely, they understand the safety hazards associated with their work, and have been made aware of the potential fire, and explosion hazards associated with work at a LPG facility.
